text: It's complicated.
This is nonsense. Constitutional rights are not civil rights. That's why the 'civil rights era' didn't happen until the mid- to late-20th century.
Too harsh. ('The worst' is really bad.)
Oh c'mon. (Deeply morally confused, sure.)
... Civil Rights are specifically (and unconstitutionally) allocated to particular protected classes. Constitutional rights never are.
If this was the case it would have required no additional legislation, such as (most notoriously) the CRA.
They are indeed violations of the constitution, and infringements of constitutional rights.
... That's what the Trump administration is now showing. Try to keep up.
How then do you frame what is happening to 'affirmative action' or 'disparate impact' redress? Prominent examples of (unconstitutional) civil rights in practice.
... DEI is entirely fabricated out of unconstitutional civil rights.
Fair enough. It's this formula that enables Trump to do everything through EOs. It's more PR than political science, though.
Okay, but it follows that 'civil rights' are not really a thing. Politically convenient fiction at this point in history at most.
Oh c'mon. "Civil rights abuses." This is completely pointless obfuscation.
No one does really believe it. It's sheer trolling.
Negative Hitlerite Theology is an existential risk.
Any hint of survival is triggering to these types.

Massive election fraud even in many seats that weren't lost. (Just not massive enough.) 
A full-spectrum election integrity investigation should be a crucial part of the Trump agenda.
... Election fraud doesn't suddenly become okay when it doesn't quite work out.
Same.
Absolutely no question there are such people (but at least they no longer typify the US military high command).

"But it's now all over. Trump won America's cold civil war by adapting an old Reaganite mantra from the days of the actual Cold War against the Soviet Union ... 'We win and they lose.'" realclearpolitics.com/articl…
"The principles of the country" are the Constitution and deep cultural canon. 'Civil Rights' add approximately nothing, and (under still dominant nefarious interpretations) subtract a lot.

The problem of electoral corruption rose to the level of lurid crisis in late 2020, the (Democrat) Jan 6 coup d'état then cemented the regime transition, and this series of events became completely impossible to investigate under the profoundly criminal Biden admin. DoJ.
All legislation should be like Anya posts that way.
Berry plays a useful role. He allows us to see what James Lindsay would be like if he wasn't a paranoid schizophrenic.
During a Turner show the Lemurs whispered "You know 'Sea  Storms' has to be good."
